content:
Placeholder for next Thursday's T-compiler meeting @T-compiler/meeting

Agenda draft is here: https://hackmd.io/A9tVDbiZSLKHMY4gCSByRw?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli
  • WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi

Hello @T-compiler/meeting; triage meeting will take place in about 2h (DST in the US!)
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

mentions for checkins:

  • WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli (previous checkin)
  • WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi (previous checkin)

Note: it would be great if today the nominated issue #47384 would be discussed (last time was briefly mentioned). Full context in the links for that issue:
https://hackmd.io/A9tVDbiZSLKHMY4gCSByRw#Nominated-Issues
(also my fault that I didn't mention that issue properly)
Hi @T-compiler/meeting ! Its time for our weekly triage meeting! Add a :wave: to show you're here!
many thanks to @apiraino and @WG-prioritization for preparing the agenda
(fyi: I'll have to leave halfway through the meeting)

Lets start off with a few minutes for

Announcements

(we're getting a later start today so I'm going to try to push a little faster through these)

• Tomorrow 2022-03-18T10:00:00-04:00 Meeting "backlog bonanza", link
    • Zulip chat from previous meeting
    • Backlog Bonanza 2022-03-16
    • HackMD live document
• Tomorrow 2022-03-18T14:00:00+01:00 Types Team: Planning/Deep-Dive meeting (calendar link)

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copyright/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "Implement Clone for generators" compiler-team#494
    • "Add import_name_type parameter to #[link]" compiler-team#495
    • "Removing codegen logic for nvptx-nvidia-cuda (32-bit target)" compiler-team#496

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 8 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: 5 months ago)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • "-Dwarnings to cover all warnings" compiler-team#473 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • "Build-time execution sandboxing" compiler-team#475 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • "Dealing with type/const ambiguities" compiler-team#480 (last review activity: about 55 days ago)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Tracking issue for Consistent no-prelude attribute (RFC 501)" rust#20561
    • "Stabilize native library modifier syntax and the whole-archive modifier specifically" rust#93901

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Increase the minimum linux-gnu versions" compiler-team#493

• Accepted MCPs
    • "allow arbitrary inherent impls in the standard library" compiler-team#487

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Tracking Issue for RFC #2972: Constrained Naked Functions " rust#90957
    • "Stabilize ADX target feature" rust#93745
    • "Stabilize const_fn_fn_ptr_basics, const_fn_trait_bound, and const_impl_trait" rust#93827
Oh, also: Something that came up during the lang team meeting yesterday
"RFC 2045: improving #[target_feature]" #44839 probably needs an owner
I'm going to take some time to separate out the target-specific stuff (which is not what I'm saying needs an owner)
from the cross-cutting issues that are not target specific; that is what I believe needs an owner
(I was reminded to mention this by the PR #93745 above)
WG checkins
• WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli (previous checkin)
(anything to report there?)

• WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi (previous checkin)

    Most notable changes

    • Edit glossary #1302
    • Edit "Queries" chapter #1301

    Most notable WIPs

    • rewrite bootstrapping stages #1327
    • Document ErrorGuaranteed #1316
    • Edit "What the compiler does to your code" #1306
    • Describe Type Alias Impl Trait (TAIT) Inference Algorithm #1297
    • Extend debugging llvm section #1290
    • Added detail to codegen section #1216
    • Document inert vs active attributes #1110
    • Explain the new valtree system for type level constants. #1097

I won't wait to see if @oli or @Esteban Küber have something to report; we can do it at the end. Lets move on to

Backport nominations
Nothing notable, a bunch of smaller improvements as usual.
I'd like to highlight https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/3191. Please leave a review/signoff as you have time. :smile:
Oh yeah, rfcs#3191 is cross cutting across T-lang and T-compiler, so its an especially long checkoff list

okay, back to

Backport nominations
T-compiler beta / T-compiler stable
Another announcement (unrelated to checkins): wg-traits is having a deep dive meeting on @nikomatsakis's a mir-formality
@Jack Huey is that the meeting tomorrow? or is wg-traits distinct from types-team ?
Same team, different name rn
It is tomorrow
well, if its a distinct timeslot from what was announced above, let us know
Sorry, thought I said that

So, first

Beta nomination

• "Revert accidental stabilization" rust#94805
    • nominated by @oli
    • Fixes P-high rust#94804
    • r'ed by @pnkfelix
    • (@apiraino relabeled to t-libs, unsure it it's correct
I was not sure if this was relevant to T-compiler
yeah I'm not sure either
the point is I guess: Who is supposed to determine where we can put the #[rustc_const_unstable(..) attributes? Does that fall under T-libs alone? Or is it T-compiler too?
@oli ^ ?
I'm in favor of backporting in any case
My understanding is that this was an accident, and we want to limit the amount of time that it can be used by accident
Let's make sure the libs team is also aware of the backports.
lets plan to backport unless someone objects.
It would be very bad for people to get used to this being stable.
Yes I was just going to say, we should probably ping T-libs (T-libs-impl?) about this
@Mara just a heads up, we want to backport #94805
we can follow up async if there are concerns
next up
hi
hi
There's an accidental stabilization
its not even clear if its a T-compiler decision or a T-libs decision
to approve the backport
but we're pretty sure this should be beta-backported
sure, sgtm :)
okay great

pnkfelix said:

the point is I guess: Who is supposed to determine where we can put the #[rustc_const_unstable(..) attributes? Does that fall under T-libs alone? Or is it T-compiler too?

it was actually a bug. adding rustc_const_unstable actually works on impls... except for Drop as it turns out
hang out for a bit and you can do the same when we bring it up again for stable
but first

• "relax suspicious_auto_trait_impls lint wrt lifetimes" rust#94925
    • PR authored by @lcnr
    • fixes this comment from issue rust#93367
there's no issue filed in rust repo that corresponds to https://github.com/Diggsey/scoped-tls-hkt/issues/2
and that issue says "nightly"
so, let me ask the dumb question: Do we have confirmation that this affects beta?
yes
okay
is there an issue filed?
https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=beta&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=
in any case, I approve a beta backport here

pnkfelix said:

is there an issue filed?

no, except for the comment in the tracking issue for the lint

lcnr said:

https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=beta&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=

you haven't provided the correct link :)
okay. my gut feeling is that its good to have issues filed in our own repo for these things, if only to e.g. have meta data tags reflecting status
but the most important thing is to do the backport
is playground linking broken? :o
and that's approved

Santiago Pastorino said:

lcnr said:

https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=beta&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=

you haven't provided the correct link :)

pub struct WithLifetime<'a, T>(&'a (), T);
unsafe impl<T> Send for WithLifetime<'static, T> {} // warns on beta

lcnr said:

is playground linking broken? :o

share -> permalink to playground works for me
hmm, interesting, after pressing share again it also works for me again
okay, onward

• "Revert accidental stabilization" rust#94805
    • Same T-libs PR also nominated for beta backport
seems pretty clear that we should include this in any future point release, I think
i doubt it motivates a point release
but that's a conversation perhaps to have with T-release
Might be a small contributing factor, if there were others, but probably not on its own?
anyway @Mara checked :back: , so I'm satisfied. Stable approved. :) Thanks for joining the game @Mara
next up

T-rustdoc beta / T-rustdoc stable

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler
I'm going to skip ahead to the nominated issues
because I saw @apiraino 's note at the top
we'll come back around to the agenda-order after we deal with this

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "no_mangle/used static is only present in output when in reachable module" rust#47384
    • @inquisitivecrystal suggested nomination (zulip comment)
    • pointing to @Josh Triplett github comment
    • the Wg-prio zulip topic has more context

apiraino said:

Note: it would be great if today the nominated issue #47384 would be discussed (last time was briefly mentioned). Full context in the links for that issue:
https://hackmd.io/A9tVDbiZSLKHMY4gCSByRw#Nominated-Issues
okay, I've read the thread from the zulip prioritization topic linked above
@inquisitivecrystal it sounds like you've already done some amount of investigation here
Yes.
Well, as far as one can do just by reading issues.
The issue is a tangled mess, but in short, it seems like a lot of the ecosystem was relying on guarantees we didn't make but followed in some cases. T-lang says the change is a regression.
sure
They're not sure whether to guarantee the behavior that people want in all cases yet.
so my reading of josh's description of the regression is that #[used] at some point stopped ensuring the symbol would be included in the object file, and that is the regression that needs to be fixed
That's my understanding as well. :thumbs_up:
and then @inquisitivecrystal wrote this at some point

inquisitivecrystal said:

No one seems to be entirely sure of what actually happened. The most compelling explanation I've heard is that we've switched from emitting llvm.used to llvm.compiler.used on all platforms, and the fix would be to only do that on ELF and still emit llvm.used everywhere else.
I basically got that from this comment. It seems like it's probably the explanation.
the best thing is probably for someone to follow up with @inquisitivecrystal 1:1 to dig into that
I'm pretty swamped today. Is there anyone else available to look into this today?
otherwise, I can try to take it up tomorrow
For now, i guess i'll assume that I'll look at it tomorrow
I can talk to you over the weekend, if need be? I'm pretty swamped till then, and am on a train all day Friday.
okay, I won't plan to chat synchronously with you until Monday perhaps. (Weekends are not easy for me as there's lots of stuff involving children distracting me.)
That's fine.
Okay sounds good
Sorry for taking up such a large chunk of this meeting.
no its okay
It's kinda terrifying to talk in one of these when I've never even attended one before.
its important that we deal with this stuff
so, back to agenda order then

Oldest PRs waiting for review

T-compiler

• "Enforce that closure: 'a requires that closure_ret_ty: 'a holds" rust#84385 (last review activity: 10 months ago)
    • assigned to and reviewed by @nikomatsakis
    • @oli flipped the flag to s-waiting-on-review
    • can remove label s-waiting-on-author, correct? (cc: @Aaron Hill)
I need to revisit that
It's probably just lost in Niko's pile
I think there was too much fallout (it required changes in libcore)
so wait, @Aaron Hill , is it indeed still waiting on stuff from you?
ah
do you need to schedule time with niko to work out another strategy here?
That sounds good
Okay
I guess my only q is whether to leave it as S-waiting-on-review
it currently has both S- flags
I think it can be waiting on author
okay
It's been a while since I've looked at it
Either that or S-experimental
@oli why did you retag #84385 as S-waiting-on-review? Just based on the comment thread?
Oh no, github says "error: You can't comment at this time"
yea
oh well. we can remove the label later.
once github is back up
thanks @oli
I also talked with niko about it real quick
I wonder how that PR interacts with lazy taits
okay.Hopefully @Aaron Hill will find a time slot to discuss. itwith niko.
(perhaps one of the existing meetings will make sense. )
It's probably too much to hope for that the inference problems will just go away :)
next up

• "Mir-Opt for copying enums with large discrepancies" rust#85158 (last review activity: 4 months ago)
    • cc: @Wesley Wiser to r+

• "Improve unsafe diagnostic" rust#91133 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • cc: @Esteban Küber
oh wait
Same as last week. I'll catch up before eow
@Wesley Wiser should we reassign rust#85158 ?
Sigh, no I'll review it right after this meeting.
/me makes note to not forget
okay. if something else comes up, don't be afraid to ask for help

• "Add debug assertions to some unsafe functions" rust#92686 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • first round of review from @Josh Triplett and @The 8472
I'm not sure about all the changes embedded here
I reviewed #91133 and r+ed it. Bors didn't pick it up, so it was still "waiting-for-review"
or maybe I misunderstand the transformation replacing get_unchecked(i) with as_ptr().add(i)

Jack Huey said:

I reviewed #91133 and r+ed it. Bors didn't pick it up, so it was still "waiting-for-review"

hmm weird. okay.
anyway I'll add an action item to also look at rust#92686. But I won't self-assign it quite yet

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 2 T-compiler P-critical issues

    • 0 of those are unassigned

  • 64 T-compiler P-high issues

    • 47 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 2 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta

  • 1 P-critical, 0 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly

  • 1 P-critical, 43 P-high, 82 P-medium, 11 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "Binary crashes when statically linked with LTO turned on" rust#94564
    • Issue has been pinned to reduce duplicates
    • bisection pointing to commit (comment)
    • @Michael Goulet (compiler-errors) self-assigned
@Michael Goulet (compiler-errors) do you have this under control?
Issue is waiting on bors, tree is closed due to CI issues... (edit: for future, agenda mixup, I was referencing #94998)
oh okay great
t-infra is working on it i think
I mean, not great, but under control
next

• "assertion failed: !value.has_escaping_bound_vars(): ICE when compiling crate tracing-subscriber v0.3.9" rust#94998
    • issue has been discussed on Zulip (comments on github)
    • @pnkfelix self-assigned
Uh wait
what's up?
94564 is assigned to Felix not Michael
and I don't see a linked PR either
ha ha
let me go look
oh yeah!
I did look at this
OH lol yes i meant my comments in response to #94998
Maybe a transposition error in agenda construction then?
so: What to do about #94564 ?
I'm not sure we can reasonably "fix" it. Should we instead detect the glibc version and warn if someone has LTO enabled along with glibc <= 2.33 ?
it also depends on -C target-feature=+crt-static, apparently
so maybe a narrowly scoped warning would be warranted?
at least, I don't have a better idea for strategy beyond that.
I'll post a comment asking the question there
argh githbu

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • "No more auto-unrolling starting with LLVM 14" rust#94847
    • bisection at this comment
(I could just now post a comment on github)
I'd say rust#94847 is in between P-high and P-medium...
I'm not terribly stressed about it, at least...

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs for 2022-03-15

Largely a quiet week. The perf improvement highlight is the use of real world crates such as syn, cargo, and serde in the collecting of profile guided optimization (PGO) profiles for LLVM. Previously only libcore was used for LLVM, though rustc PGO had more crates involved. This led to some decent improvement in compilation of real world crates (upwards of 5.5%).

On the regression side, the regressions were all largely small but contained inside of rollups making them hard to diagnose and correct. The perf team continues to work on process improvements that make changes to the compiler land through CI quickly while minimizing perf regressions that can sneak through.

Triage done by @rylev.
Revision range: 10dccdc7fcbdc64ee9efe2c1ed975ab8c1d61287..3ba1ebea122238d1a5c613deb1bf60ce24bd8fd8

2 Regressions, 3 Improvements, 3 Mixed; 3 of them in rollups
27 Untriaged Pull Requests
42 comparisons made in total
And. ... i have to go to another meeting. Sorry all!
See you all at the design meeting tomorrow!
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!

Draft for next weeks' agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/43XK8_4NROi5sowR1Qb35Q

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-traits (impl trait) by @nikomatsakis
  • WG-llvm by @nagisa and @Nikita Popov
